task.title: Creating a DITA topic
task.shortdesc: DITA (Darwin Information Typing Architecture) is an XML-based markup language commonly used for creating structured documentation. DITA topics are the fundamental building blocks of DITA content. In this task topic, you will learn how to create a DITA topic.

ul.li: A text editor or an XML editor (such as Oxygen XML Editor or Adobe FrameMaker). You can download a trial version of the Oxygen XML Author at Oxygen Download.
Basic knowledge of the subject matter you want to document.

context.p: Once you complete the instructions, you will have a task topic created.

step.cmd: On you system, open Oxyegn XML.
On top left of the Oxygen XML, select File New . Alternatively, select the New icon.
step.stepresult: You will now see the New window.

step.cmd: From the available template list, select one of the following DITA topic templates:

chdesc.p: The Concept topic type is used to provide fundamental explanations and background information about a particular subject. It aims to answer "What is it?" and helps users grasp the underlying concepts and principles related to a topic.

The Task topic type is designed to guide users through a series of steps to accomplish a specific goal or perform a task. It answers the question "How do I do it?" and provides detailed, sequential instructions.

The Reference topic type is intended for providing comprehensive and detailed information about specific elements, parameters, or features. It serves as a reference guide, answering "What are the details?" and provides in-depth information.

step.cmd: Locate the Title field in the template, and enter the title of your topic.

info.note: Do not insert special characters or exceed 255 character limit while providing a title.

step.cmd: Browse and choose the location to save the file.

result.p: You have now created the DITA topic of your choice.

postreq.p: Now that you have created a DITA topic, start adding the content, use bulleted or numbered lists, insert images or diagrams, add cross-references, etc.
